entry.et: Middle English sent, from Anglo-French sente, from sentir

def.dt: :effluvia from a substance that affect the sense of smell: as
:an odor left by an animal on a surface passed over
:power of smelling :sense of smell a keen scent
:power of detection :nose a scent for heresy
:a course of pursuit or discovery throw one off the scent
:bits of paper dropped in the game of hare and hounds
:a mixture prepared for use as a lure in hunting or fishing

entry.et: Middle English senten, from Anglo-French sentir to feel, smell, from Latin sentire to perceive, feel sense

def.dt: :to get or have an inkling of scent trouble
:to imbue or fill with odor scented the air with perfume
:to yield an odor of some specified kind this scents of sulfur
:to use the nose in seeking or tracking prey
:a hound (as a bloodhound) that hunts and pursues game by scent rather than by sight compare sight hound
